Jckker

What is the difference? Easy: Imagine a scale, this scale has two ends to it, Capitalism and Socialism (spelling?). Now on this scale, we have two markers, Republican and Democrat. The Republican marker will be close, but not on, the Capitalist end, more than half way, about that 1/4th mark towards Capitalism; while the Democratic marker is very close to the Socialist end, almost right on it. Neither political party is on a end, and neither ever will be, and none will ever be in the middle.
 
 Anyway, that is the way I see political parties. Comparing thier views with those of the tw major economic models.
Symbiote

The Republican marker will be close, but not on, the Capitalist end... while the Democratic marker is very close to the Socialist end

 
 If that were true, there really would be differences between the parties. 
 
 In truth, both parties desire to expand government , not largely because of any traditional ideological reason, but rather to pay off their corporate sponsors, pursue their pet projects and increase their power.
 
 The idea that they honestly adhere to any belief system is just an illusion foisted on the public.

Bush is even obliged to those extremes in American cities because he fears the American people so much.

If there is no difference between the two parties in Europe and the rest of the world.

 
 Um. Dear. Are you serious? Here's a crash course in European Politics. 
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_political_party#The_parties
 
 Furthermore, their proportional representation creates situations and relationships far different then our own system. Remember when both parties tried to court the 1 independent in the senate? Imagine that a million folds over. Leaders form coalitions of parties, not relying upon 1 party. 
 
 Furthermore the idea that the National Front is no different then Socialists is asinine.
obvious_child

Even I, the most ignorant on economy in the room, recognize that as a big fat liberal claim. Clinton came no where close to eliminating the national debt.
 
 His 'surplus' was generated by his voodoo accounting methods.

 
 This is sort of true. Clinton had a actual surplus of around 50 million. In a 2.1 trillion budget that's nothing. However, that budget doesn't account for off balance sheet financing, such as the postal service. Once you add those in, the surplus goes away. So on the B/S he actually did have a tiny surplus. off the B/s It didn't exist.
 
 And you're right, Clinton didn't even come close to eliminating the National debt. Still, you have to give him credit that the rate of increase was pretty low. Unlike his successor....
conservative

At this point, noone could ever eliminate the debt, in my opinion. I believe a lack of cooperation caused the deficit problems in the 80s. The democratic congressmen would not reduce/eliminate funding for many programs that Reagan accounted for in his economic plan. Also Reagan would not sacrifice his tax cuts or his military spending. Therefore, we have no more Cold War, but a massive debt.
 
 The way I see it... there really isn't much difference in the goals. The farthest right want to completely eliminate government through giving people absolute freedom. The farthest left want to eventually eliminate government through restrictions of everything to the point of a routine. The two absolutes go so far apart that they go all the way around and meet in the middle. 
 
 In short, the eventual goal is the same: to eventually destroy government completely in a utopian society. The differences are the way they go about it. These are just my thoughts, so what do you think?
